Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Phase 3 Design, Implementation and Dissemination of Multidisciplinary Online Java-Digital Signal Processing (J-DSP) Materials

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engineering - Other (59)

The project, a collaboration involving Arizona State University (ASU) as the lead institution, Johns Hopkins University (JHU), University of Washington-Bothell (UWB), Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU), and Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology (RHIT), is expanding the use of an award winning software package (J-DSP) and instructional approach into a broad set of new areas including digital signal processing, earth systems and geology, renewable energy systems, arts and media, ion-channel systems, and genomics. Online modules are being designed, deployed, and assessed by a geographically-diverse multidisciplinary team. This educational technology provides free and universally accessible web-based Java software with an intuitive interface that enables instructors to create web-based lectures with synchronized online simulations and animations and to monitor student progress and preferences. It allows students, including distance learners, to conduct online laboratories and collaborate across disciplines, to perform simulations anytime anywhere, and to collaborate online with their colleagues at other universities. The evaluation effort is using self, peer, and instructor assessments to measure the quality of student learning by adapting a set of on-line assessment instruments developed on a previous grant dealing with a set of signal processing courses. The project team is working to disseminate the instructional materials by postings on the project's website and on a discipline-based site (CNX.ORG), by links with the NSDL, by faculty workshops, by conference presentation and journal publications, and by high school and industrial outreach. Broader impacts include an involvement of two MSIs, an outreach effort focused on minorities, multifaceted dissemination involving faculty workshops and web posting on several sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
J-DSP is an open software developed by Arizona State University, which provides a free and easy accessible web-based calculation and simulation platform for students and general public including distance learners to use in related courses like digital signal processing. As an indispensible component in the national dissemination plan, Prairie View A&M University (PVAMU) with a historical black tradition represents its applications to benefit the underrepresented minorities.

 

1. intellectual merit: Propelled by this NSF project, PI led the departmental efforts to revamp curriculums and strengthen the education in the emerging area of digital signal processing. Three new degree courses as well as corresponding laboratory courses  have been established for Electrical Engineering Technology program and Computer Engineering Technology program, and J-DSP have been continuously utilized in related courses to prepare students in utilizing open and free online resources to conduct simulation and calculation.  Following with J-DSP, PI gradually enriched his own online laboratory teaching modules with various developing tools as well as other application areas including power engineering technology.   

 

2. broader impact: Over ninety percent of the undergraduate population at PVAMU is African Americans, many are first generation college students and/or with financially disadvantageous background. By means of web-based open software, students can get easy access to the simulation and calculation tools without financial burden, greatly improved teaching and learning environment. Every year, one group of students worked with PI to develop teaching modules to enrich online courseware, and graduate students are hired to help undergraduates in senior projects as well as teaching laboratories. Research and education achievements were disseminated through open houses, meetings, symposiums, seminars, workshops, conferences, etc. Besides, attendees in faculty workshops not only discussed the educational innovations including online laboratories, but also envisioned the sustainable development strategies for Engineering Technology.
